discussion.content: Plenum helps reduce the chances of people dying from toxic fumes when a building is burning down. If its going into the walls, use plenum.

Selected Answer: D
D is the answer. I'm just glad they finally changed some of these answers to the correct ones.

Selected Answer: D
D - Plenum-rated cable produces minimal amounts of smoke if burned, must be selfextinguishing,
and must meet other strict fire safety standards.
There are no other options which fits the best answer. Plenum
my guess would be they are implying a drop ceiling which you will usually see air ducts above it.

comments.content:
The Teflon-type covering is frequently referred to as a plenum-rated coating, and it’s
definitely expensive but often mandated by local or municipal fire code when cable is hidden in walls and ceilings. Non-plenum cables can actually become “wicks” for the fire, helping it quickly spread from room to room and floor to floor.
Whenever running Ethernet in a ceiling, you should always use plenum-rated cabling

discussion.content: Why Plenum, it's in the ceiling area, NOT in any ductwork?

questions.question_text:
A network administrator migrated the data for the corporate email service from one provider to another. All DNS records were successfully changed and verified.
However, many hours later, users are still receiving new emails on the old provider's server. Which of the following should the administrator perform NEXT to troubleshoot the issue?

choices.B: Remove old SPF records from the DNS host.
choices.D: Check the TTL value on the MX records.
choices.A: Add a secondary MX server to the DNS records.
choices.C: Create a DMARC record that includes the old server.

discussion.content: I just hope I dont get this question on this stupid exam.

I believe the answer is D: check the TTL value on the MX records. You can reduce the amount of time email will be going to the old provider after the change by lowing the TTL on the DNS records before you make the change.

comments.content: D is for me only reasonable..
yes, but do not specify where mail will flow... definitely not B

discussion.content:
I think that B is the right answer. 

SPF specifies the mail servers that are allowed to send email for your domain.
I wish someone would explain this answer. What's going on with a "secondary MX"?

comments.content: The given answer doesn't look right. particularly because it asks what to do NEXT. i think one4u2h8 is on to something
So you're saying that it's D?

discussion.content: Note that changing a record's TTL affects how long it will take any subsequent change to happen. We recommend setting a TTL value of 3600, which tells servers across the Internet to check every hour for updates to the record. The shorter TTL will only take effect after the prior period expires. This means that next time you update the record, your change will take up to one hour to go into effect. To make subsequent changes happen even more quickly—for example, if you think you might want to quickly revert a change—you can set a shorter TTL, such as 300 seconds (5 minutes). Once the records are configured correctly, we recommend setting a TTL value of 86400, which tells servers across the Internet to check every 24 hours for updates to the record.
Not B?

questions.question_text: A network administrator needs to extend an organization's network to a nearby building that has unused SMF already installed. The network administrator has decided to create a switch-to-switch uplink. Which of the following standards would be the BEST to use?

discussion.content: 1000BASE-SX uses *only* Multi-Mode Fiber MMF.

1000BASE-LX...this version of Gigabit Ethernet is intended for use with long-wavelength transmissions (1270–1355 nm) over long cable runs of fiber optic cabling. 1000BASE-LX can run over both single mode fiber and multimode fiber with a distance of up to 5 km
